tgt_text.16: and, having devoted his whole life to the search after and the inculcation of religious, philosophical, and moral truth, resolved to bear himself in this extremity in a manner con­ sistent with his established character, and to take his stand on his own integrity and innocence, utterly uninfluenced by that imaginary evil, death.

tgt_text.18: In his discussions with others, on what­ ever subject, it was his constant habit to keep his opponents to the question before them, and he would never suffer them to evade it, but by a connected series of the most subtle questions or arguments compelled them to retract any erroneous opinion they might have advanced:

tgt_text.20: With regard to the first accusation, that he did not believe in the established religion, he neither confesses nor denies it, but shews that he had in some instances conformed to the religious customs of his country, and that he did believe in God, so much so indeed that even if they would acquit him on condition of his abandoning his practice of teaching others, he could not consent to such terms, but must persevere in ful­ filling the mission on which the Deity had sent him, for that he feared God rather than man.
tgt_text.21: With reference to the second charge which he meets first, by his usual method of a brief but close cross-examination of his accuser Melitus, he brings him to this dilemma, that he must either charge him with cor­ rupting the youth designedly, which would be absurd, or with doing so undesignedly, for which he could not be liable to punishment.

tgt_text.363: I then should be acting strangely, 0 Athenians, if, when the generals whom you chose to command me assigned me my post at Potidsea, at Amphipolis, and at Delium, I then remained where they posted me, like any other person, and encountered the danger of death, but when the deity as I thought and be­ lieved, assigned it as my duty to pass my life in the study of philosophy, and in examining myself and others, I should on that occasion, through fear of death or any thing else whatso­ ever, desert my post.
tgt_text.364: Strange indeed would it be, and then in truth any one might justly bring me to trial, and accuse me of not believing in the gods, from disobeying the oracle, fearing death, and thinking myself to be wise when I am not.
tgt_text.365: For to fear death, 0 Athenians, is nothing else than to appear to be wise, without being so;
tgt_text.366: for it is to appear to know what one does not know.
tgt_text.367: For no one knows but that death is the greatest of all goods to man ;
tgt_text.368: but men fear it, as if they well knew that it is the greatest of evils.

tgt_text.372: But to act unjustly, and to disobey my superior, whether God or man, I know is evil and base.

tgt_text.376: " 0 Athenians, I honour and love you:
tgt_text.377: but I shall obey God rather than you ;
tgt_text.378: and as long as I breathe and am able, I shall not cease studying philosophy, and exhorting you and warning any one of you I may happen to meet, saying as I have been ac­ customed to do:
tgt_text.379: '0 best of men, seeing you are an Athenian, of a city the most powerful and most renowned for wisdom and strength, are you not ashamed of being careful for riches, how you may acquire them in greatest abundance, and for glory and honour, but care not nor take any thought for wisdom and truth, and for your soul, how it may be made most perfect ?' "
tgt_text.380: And if any one of you should question my assertion, and affirm that he does care for these things, I shall not at once let him go, nor depart, but I shall question him, sift and prove him.

tgt_text.399: Now, therefore, 0 Athenians, I am far from making a defence on my own behalf, as any one might think, but I do so on your behalf, lest by condemning me you should offend at all with respect to the gift of the deity to you.
tgt_text.400: For, if you should put me to death, you will not easily find such another, though it may be ridi­ culous to say so, altogether attached by the deity to this city as to a powerful and generous horse, somewhat sluggish from his size, and requiring to be roused by a gad-fly;
tgt_text.401: so the deity appears to have united me, being such a person as I am, to the city, that I may rouse you, and persuade and reprove every one of you, nor ever cease besetting you throughout the whole day.

tgt_text.405: But that I am a person who has been given by the deity to this city, you may discern from hence;

tgt_text.469: Perhaps, however, some among you will be indignant on recollecting his own case, if he, when engaged in a cause far less than this, implored and besought the judges with many tears, bringing forward his children in order that he might ex­ cite their utmost compassion, and many others of his relatives and friends, whereas I do none of these things, although I may appear to be incurring the extremity of danger.
tgt_text.470: Perhaps, therefore, some one, taking notice of this, may become more determined against me, and, being enraged at this very con­ duct of mine, may give his vote under the influence of anger.
tgt_text.471: If then any one of you is thus affected,—I do not however suppose that there is,-but if there should be, I think I may reasonably say to him ;
tgt_text.473: I too, 0 best of men, have relatives;
tgt_text.474: for to make use of that saying of Homer, I am not sprung from an oak, nor from a rock, but from men, so that I too, 0 Athe­ nians, have relatives, and three sons, one now grown up, and two boys:
tgt_text.475: I shall not however bring any one of them forward and implore you to acquit me.
tgt_text.476: Why then shall I not do this ?
tgt_text.477: Not from contumacy, 0 Athenians, nor disrespect towards you.
tgt_text.478: Whether or not I am undaunted at the prospect of death, is another question, but out of regard to my own character, and yours, and that of the whole city, it does not appear to me to be honourable that I should do any thing of this kind at my age, and with the reputation I have, whether true or false.
tgt_text.479: For it is commonly agreed that Socrates in some respects excels the generality of men.
tgt_text.480: If, then, those among you who appear to excel either in wisdom, or fortitude, or any other virtue whatsoever, should act in such a manner as I have often seen some when they have been brought to trial, it would be shameful, who appearing indeed to be something, have con­ ducted themselves in a surprising manner, as thinking they should suffer something dreadful by dying, and as if they would be immortal if you did not put them to death.
tgt_text.481: Such men appear to me to bring disgrace on the city, so that any stranger might suppose that such of the Athenians as excel in virtue, and whom they themselves choose in preference to them­ selves for magistracies and other honours, are in no respect superior to women.
tgt_text.482: For these things, 0 Athenians, neither ought we to do who have attained to any height of reputa­ tion, nor, should we do them, ought you to suffer us;
tgt_text.483: but you should make this manifest, that you will much rather condemn him who introduces these piteous dramas, and makes the city ridiculous, than him who quietly awaits your decision.
tgt_text.484: 24. But reputation apart, 0 Athenians, it does not appear to me to be right to entreat a judge, or to escape by en­ treaty, but one ought to inform and persuade him.
tgt_text.485: For a judge does not sit for the purpose of administering justice out of favour, but that he may judge rightly, and he is sworn not to shew favour to whom he pleases, but that he will decide ac­ cording to the laws.
tgt_text.486: It is therefore right that neither should we accustom you, nor should you accustom yourselves to violate your oaths;
tgt_text.487: for in so doing neither of us would act righteously.
tgt_text.488: -Think not then, 0 Athenians, that I ought to adopt such a course towards you as I neither consider honourable, nor just, nor holy, as well, by Jupiter, on any other occasion, and now especially when I am accused of impiety by this Melitus.
tgt_text.489: For clearly, if I should persuade you, and by my entreaties should put a constraint on you who are bound by an oath, I should teach you to think that there are no gods, and in reality, while making my defence, should accuse myself of not believing in the gods.
tgt_text.490: This, however, is far from being the case:

tgt_text.1026: This, again, seems a contradic­ tion to Simmias, but Socrates explains it by shewing that our souls are placed in the body by God, and may not leave it without His permission.

tgt_text.1028: Socra­ tes, therefore, proposes to plead his cause before them, and to shew that there is a great probability that after this life he shall go into the presence of God and good men, and be happy in proportion to the purity of his own mind.
tgt_text.1029: He beginsa by stating that philosophy itself is nothing else than a preparation for and meditation on death.
tgt_text.1030: Death and philosophy have this in common :
tgt_text.1031: death separates the soul from the body, philosophy draws off the mind from bodily things to the contemplation of truth and virtue:
tgt_text.1032: for he is not a true philosopher who is led away by bodily pleasures, since the senses are the source of ignorance and all evil;
tgt_text.1033: the mind, therefore, is entirely occupied in meditating on death, and freeing itself as much as possible from the body.
tgt_text.1034: How, then, can such a man be afraid of death ?

tgt_text.1036: And, indeed, most men are temperate through intemperance, that is to say, they abstain from some pleasures that they may the more easily and permanently en­ joy others.

tgt_text.1038: Whereas the philosopher purifies his mind from all such things, and pursues virtue and wisdom for their own sakes.

tgt_text.1041: Upon this Cebesb says that he-agrees with all else that had been said, but cannot help entertaining doubts of what will be­ come of the soul when separated from the body, for the com­ mon opinion is that it is dispersed and vanishes like breath or smoke, and no longer exists any where.
tgt_text.1042: Socrates, therefore, proposes to enquire into the probability of the case, a fit em­ ployment for him under his present circumstances.
tgt_text.1043: His first argumentc is drawn from the ancient belief preva­ lent amongst men, that souls departing hence exist in Hades, and are produced again from the dead.
tgt_text.1044: If this be true, it must follow that our souls are there, for they could not be pro­ duced again if they did not exist:
tgt_text.1045: and its truth is confirmed by this, that it is a general law of nature that contraries are produced from contraries, the greater from the less, strong from weak, slow from swift, heat from cold, and in like man­ ner life from death, and vice versd.
tgt_text.1046: To explain this more clearly, he proceeds to shew that what is changed passes from one state to another, and so undergoes three different states, first the actual state, then the transition, and thirdly the new state, as from a state of sleep, by awaking to being awake :
tgt_text.1047: in like manner birth is a transition from a state of death to life, and dying from life to death, so that the soul, by the act of dying, only passes to another state;
tgt_text.1048: if it were not so, all nature would in time become dead, just as if people did not awake out of sleep all would at last be buried in eternal sleep.
tgt_text.1049: Whence the conclusion is that the souls of men are not anni­ hilated by death.
tgt_text.1050: Cebesd agrees to this reasoning, and adds that he is further convinced of its truth by calling to mind an argument used by Socrates on former occasions, that knowledge is nothing but reminiscence, and if this is so, the soul must have existed and had knowledge before it became united to the body.
tgt_text.1051: But in case Simmias should not yet be satisfied, Socrates e proceeds to enlarge on this, his second argument, drawn from reminiscence.
tgt_text.1052: We daily find that we are carried from the knowledge of one thing to another.
tgt_text.1053: Things perceived by the eyes, ears, and other senses, bring up the thought of other things :
tgt_text.1054: thus the sight of a lyre or a garment reminds us of a friend, and not only are we thus reminded of sensible objects, but of things which are comprehended by the mind alone, and have no sensitive existence.
tgt_text.1055: For we have formed in our minds an idea of abstract equality, of the beautiful, the just, the good, in short, of every thing which we say exists without the aid of the senses, for we use them only in the perception of individual things, whence it follows that the mind did not acquire this knowledge in this life, but must have had it before, and there­ fore the soul must have existed before.
tgt_text.1056: Simmias and Cebesf both agree in admitting that Socrates has proved the pre-existence of the soul, but insist that he has not shewn it to be immortal, for that nothing hinders but that, according to the popular opinion, it may be dispersed at the dissolution of the body.
tgt_text.1057: To which Socrates replies, that if their former admissions are joined to his last argument, the immortality, as well as the pre-existence of the soul, has been sufficiently proved.

tgt_text.1061: In order therefore to a thing being capable of dis­ persion it must be compounded of parts.
tgt_text.1062: Now there are two kinds of things, one compounded, the other simple, the former kind is subject to change, the latter not, and can be compre­ hended by the mind alone.
tgt_text.1063: The one is visible, the other in­ visible ;
tgt_text.1064: and the soul, which is invisible, when it employs the bodily senses wanders and is confused, but when it abstracts itself from the body it attains to the knowledge of that which is eternal, immortal, and unchangeable.
tgt_text.1065: The soul, therefore, being uncompounded and invisible must be indissoluble, that is to say immortal.

tgt_text.1068: And Cebes, though he admits that the soul is more durable than the body, yet objects that it is not therefore of necessity immortal but may in time wear out, and it is by no means clear that this is not its last period.
tgt_text.1069: These objections produce a powerful effect on the rest of the company, but Socrates, undismayed, exhorts them not to suffer themselves to be deterred from seeking the truth by any difficulties they may meet with;

tgt_text.1315: Does not then," he continued, " the whole employment of such a man appear to you to be, not about the body, but to separate himself from it as much as possible, and be occupied about his soul ?"" It does."“
tgt_text.1316: First of all then, in such matters, does not the philoso­ pher, above all other men, evidently free his soul as much as he call from communion with the body ?" " It appears so."25.
tgt_text.1317: "And it appears, Simmias, to the generality of men, that he who takes no pleasure in such things, and who does not use them, does not deserve to live ;
tgt_text.1318: but that he nearly ap­ proaches to death who cares nothing for the pleasures that subsist through the body.""
tgt_text.1320: But what with respect to the acquisition of wisdom, is the body an impediment or not, if any one takes it with him as a partner in the search ?
tgt_text.1322: Do sight and hearing convey any truth to men, or are they such as the poets constantly sing, who say that we neither bear nor see any thing with accuracy ?
tgt_text.1323: If however these bodily senses are neither ac­ curate nor clear, much less can the others be so:
tgt_text.1324: for they are all far inferior to these.
tgt_text.1325: Do they not seem so to you ?"" Certainly," he replied.26. " When then," said he, " does the soul light on the truth ?
tgt_text.1326: for, when it attempts to consider any thing in conjunc­ tion with the body, it is plain that it is then led astray by it."“
tgt_text.1328: Must it not then be by reasoning, if at all, that any of the things that really are become known to it ?"" Yes.""
tgt_text.1329: And surely the soul then reasons best when none of these things disturb it, neither hearing, nor sight, nor pain, nor pleasure of any kind, but it retires as much as possible within itself, taking leave of the body, and, as far as it can, not com­ municating or being in contact with it, it aims at the discovery of that which is.""
tgt_text.1331: Does not then the soul of the philosopher, in these cases, despise the body, and flee from it, and seek to retire within it­ self ?”"
tgt_text.1333: But what as to such things as these, Simmias?
tgt_text.1334: Do we say that justice itself is something or nothing ?
tgt_text.1336: "We say it is something, by Jupiter.""
tgt_text.1337: And that beauty and goodness are something ?"•" How not ?"" Now then have you ever seen any thing of this kind with your eyes ?"" By no means," he replied."
tgt_text.1338: Did you ever lay hold of them by any other bodily sense ?
tgt_text.1339: but I speak generally, as of magnitude, health, strength, and, in a word, of the essence of every thing, that is to say, what each is.
tgt_text.1340: Is then the exact truth of these perceived by means of the body, or is it thus, whoever amongst us habituates himself to reflect most deeply and accurately on each several thing about which he is considering, he will make the nearest approach to the knowledge of it ?"" Certainly."28. "
tgt_text.1341: Would not he, then, do this with the utmost purity, who should in the highest degree approach each subject by means of the mere mental faculties, neither employing the sight in conjunction with the reflective faculty, nor introducing any other sense together with reasoning ;
tgt_text.1342: but who, using pure re­ flection by itself, should attempt to search out each essence purely by itself, freed as much as possible from the eyes and ears, and, in a word, from the whole body, as disturbing the soul, and not suffering it to acquire truth and wisdom, when it is in communion with it.
tgt_text.1343: Is not he the person, Sim­ mias, if any one can, who will arrive at the knowledge of that which is ?"29. "You speak with wonderful truth, Socrates," replied Simmias.
tgt_text.1344: "Wherefore," he said, " it necessarily follows from all this, that some such opinion as this should be entertained by genuine philo­ sophers, so that they should speak among themselves as follows :
tgt_text.1346: A by-path, as it were, seems to lead us on in our researches undertaken by reason,' because as long as we are encumbered with the body, and our soul is contaminated with such an evil, we can never fully attain to what we desire ;
tgt_text.1347: and this, we say, is truth.
tgt_text.1348: For the body subjects us to innumerable hindrances on account of its necessary support, and moreover if any diseases befal us, they impede us in our search after that which is;
tgt_text.1349: and it fills us with longings, desires, fears, all kinds of fancies, and a multitude of absurdities, so that, as it is said in real truth, by reason of the body it is never possible for us to make any ad­ vances in wisdom.
tgt_text.1350: 30. " For nothing else but the body and its desires occasion wars, seditions, and contests;
tgt_text.1351: for all wars amongst us arise on account of our desire to acquire wealth;
tgt_text.1352: and we are compelled to acquire wealth on account of the body, being enslaved to its service;
tgt_text.1353: and consequently on all these accounts we are hindered in the pursuit of philosophy.
tgt_text.1354: But the worst of all is, that if it leaves us any leisure, and we apply ourselves to the consideration of any subject, it constantly obtrudes itself in the midst of our researches, and occasions trouble and disturbance, and confounds us so that we are not able by reason of it to discern the truth.
tgt_text.1355: It has then in reality been demonstrated to us, that if we are ever to know any thing purely, we must be separated from the body, and contem­ plate the things themselves by the mere soul.
tgt_text.1356: And then, as it seems, we shall obtain that which we desire, and which we profess ourselves to be lovers of, wisdom, when we are dead, as reason shews, but not while we are alive.
tgt_text.1357: 31. For if it is not possible to know any thing purely in conjunction with the body, one of these two things must follow, either that we can never acquire knowledge, or only after we are dead;
tgt_text.1358: for then the soul will subsist apart by itself, separate from the body, but not before.
tgt_text.1359: And while we live, we shall thus, as it seems, approach nearest to knowledge, if we hold no intercourse or communion at all with the body, except what absolute necessity requires, nor suffer ourselves to be pol­ luted by its nature, but purify ourselves from it, until God himself shall release us.
tgt_text.1360: And thus being pure, and freed from the folly of body, we shall in all likelihood be with others like ourselves, and shall of ourselves know the whole real essence, and that probably is truth;
tgt_text.1361: for it is not allowable for the im­ pure to attain to the pure.
tgt_text.1362: Such things, I think, Simmias, all true lovers of wisdom must both think and say to one another.
tgt_text.1363: Does it not seem so to you ?""
tgt_text.1364: Most assuredly, Socrates."32. " If this then," said Socrates, "is true, my friend, there is great hope for one who arrives where I am going, there, if any where, to acquire that in perfection for the sake of which we have taken so much pains during our past life;
tgt_text.1365: so that the journey now appointed me is set out upon with good hope, and will be so by any other man who thinks that his mind has been as it were purified.""
tgt_text.1367: But does not purification consist in this, as was said in a former part of our discourse, in separating as much as possible the soul from the body, and in accustoming it to gather and collect itself by itself on all sides apart from the body, and to dwell, as far as it can, both now and hereafter, alone by itself, delivered as it were from the shackles of the body ?""
tgt_text.1368: Certainly," he replied.33. “ Is this then called death, this deliverance and separa­ tion of the soul from the body ?" " Assuredly," he answered.
tgt_text.1369: But, as we affirmed, those who pursue philosophy rightly, are especially and alone desirous to deliver it, and this is the very study of philosophers, the deliverance and separation of the soul from the body, is it not ?""
tgt_text.1371: "Then, as I said at first, would it not be ridiculous for a man who has endeavoured throughout his life to live as near as possible to death, then, when death arrives, to grieve ?
tgt_text.1375: "In reality then, Simmias," he continued, "those who pursue philosophy rightly study to die;
tgt_text.1376: and to them of all men death is least formidable.
tgt_text.1378: Since they altogether hate the body and desire to keep the soul by it­ self, would it not be irrational if, when this comes to pass, they should be afraid and grieve, and not be glad to go to that place, where on their arrival they may hope to obtain that which they longed for throughout life;
tgt_text.1380: and to be freed from association with that which they hated ?
tgt_text.1381: 34. Have many of their own accord wished to descend into Hades, on account of human objects of affection, their wives and sons, induced by this very hope of there seeing and being with those whom they have loved;
tgt_text.1382: and shall one who really loves wisdom, and firmly cherishes this very hope, that he shall no where else attain it in a manner worthy of the name, except in Hades, be grieved at dying, and not gladly go there?
tgt_text.1383: We must think that he would gladly go, my friend, if he be in truth a philosopher;
tgt_text.1384: for he will be firmly persuaded of this, that he will no where else but there attain wisdom in its purity;
tgt_text.1385: and if this be so, would it not be very irrational, as I just now said, if such a man were to be afraid of death ?"“
tgt_text.1386: Very much so, by Jupiter," he replied.35.
tgt_text.1387: "Would not this then," he resumed, "be a sufficient proof to you, with respect to a man whom you should see grieved when about to die, that he was not a lover of wisdom but a lover of his body ?
tgt_text.1388: and this same person is probably a lover of riches and a lover of honour, one or both of these.""
tgt_text.1389: It certainly is as you say," he replied.“
tgt_text.1390: Does not then," he said, " that which is called fortitude, Simmias, eminently belong to philosophers ?"“ By all means," he answered.“
tgt_text.1391: And temperance also, which even the multitude call temperance, and which consists in not being carried away by the passions, but in holding them in contempt, and keep­ ing them in subjection, does not this belong to those only who most despise the body, and live in the study of philosophy ?"" Necessarily so," he replied.
tgt_text.1392: 36. “For,” he continued, "if you will consider the forti­ tude and temperance of others, they will appear to you to be absurd.""
tgt_text.1394: Do you know," he said, " that all others consider death among the great evils ?""
tgt_text.1396: "Then do the brave amongst them endure death, when they do endure it, through dread of greater evils ?""
tgt_text.1398: All men, therefore, except philosophers, are brave through being afraid and fear;
tgt_text.1399: though it is absurd that any one should be brave through fear and cowardice."" Certainly.""
tgt_text.1400: But what, are not those amongst them who keep their passions in subjection, affected in the same way ?
tgt_text.1401: and are they not temperate through a kind of intemperance ?
tgt_text.1402: and although we may say, perhaps, that this is.
tgt_text.1403: impossible, nevertheless the manner in which they are affected with respect to this silly temperance resembles this;
tgt_text.1404: for, fearing to be deprived of other pleasures, and desiring them, they abstain from some, being mastered by others.
tgt_text.1405: And though they call intemperance the being governed by pleasures, yet it happens to them that, by being mastered by some pleasures, they master others;
tgt_text.1406: and this is similar to what was just now said, that in a certain manner they become temperate through intemperance.""
tgt_text.1408: "37. " My dear Simmias, consider that this is not a right exchange for virtue, to barter pleasures for pleasures, pains for pains, fear for fear, and the greater for the lesser, like pieces of money;
tgt_text.1409: but that that alone is the right coin, for which we ought to barter all these things, wisdom;
tgt_text.1410: and for this, and with this every thing is in reality bought and sold, fortitude, temperance, and justice, and, in a word, true virtue subsists with wisdom, whether pleasures and fears, and every thing else of the kind, are present or absent;
tgt_text.1411: but when sepa­ rated from wisdom, and changed one for another, consider whether such virtue is not a mere outline, and in reality servile, possessing neither soundness nor truth ;
tgt_text.1412: but the really true virtue is a purification from all such things, and tempe­ rance, justice, fortitude, and wisdom itself, are a kind of initi­ atory purification.

And those who instituted the mysteries for us appear to have been by no means contemptible, but in reality to have intimated long since that whoever shall arrive in Hades unexpiated and uninitiated shall lie in mud, hut he that arrives there purified and initiated, shall dwell with the gods.
tgt_text.1415: For there are,' say those who preside at the mysteries, ‘ many wand-bearers, but few inspired.'
tgt_text.1416: These last, in my opinion, are no other than those who have pursued philo­ sophy rightly :
tgt_text.1417: that I might be of their number, I have, to the utmost of my ability, left no means untried, but have endeavoured to the utmost of my power.
tgt_text.1418: But whether I have endeavoured rightly and have in any respect succeeded, on arriving there I shall know clearly, if it please God, very shortly, as it appears to me.
tgt_text.1420: Such then, Simmias and Cebes," he added, .. is the defence I make, for that I, on good grounds, do not repine or grieve at leaving you and my masters here, being persuaded that there, no less than here, I shall meet with good masters and friends.
tgt_text.1421: But to the multitude this is incredible.
tgt_text.1422: If however I have succeeded better with you in my defence than I did with the Athenian judges, it is well.
tgt_text.1423: "When Socrates had thus spoken, Cebes, taking up the dis­ cussion said, " Socrates, all the rest appears to me to be said rightly, but what , you have said respecting the soul will occasion much incredulity in many from the apprehension that, when it is separated from the body, it no longer exists any where, but is destroyed and perishes on the very day in which a man dies, and that immediately it is separated and goes out from the body, it is dispersed and vanishes like breath or smoke, and is no longer any where;
tgt_text.1424: since, if it remained any where united in itself, and freed from those evils which you have just now enumerated, there would be an abundant and good hope, Socrates, that what you say is true.
tgt_text.1425: 40. But this probably needs no little persuasion and proof, that the soul of a man who dies, exists, and possesses activity and intelligence." \"
tgt_text.1426: You say truly, Cebes," said Socrates, " but what shall we do ?
tgt_text.1427: Are you willing that we should converse on these points, whether such is probably the case or not ?"" Indeed," replied Cebes, " I should gladly hear your opinion on these matters.
tgt_text.1428: ""I do not think," said Socrates, " that any one who should now hear us, even though he were a comic poet, would say that I am talking idly, or discoursing on subjects that do not concern me.
tgt_text.1429: If you please, then, we will examine into it.
tgt_text.1430: Let us consider it in this point of view, whether the souls of men who are dead exist in Hades, or not.
tgt_text.1431: This is an ancient say­ ing, which we now call to mind, that souls departing hence exist there, and return hither again, and are produced from the dead.
tgt_text.1432: 41. And if this is so, that the living are produced again from the dead, can there be any other consequence than that our souls- are there ?
tgt_text.1433: for surely they could not be pro­ duced again if they did not exist;
tgt_text.1434: and this would be a sum­ dent proof that these things.
tgt_text.1435: are so, if it should in reality be evident that the living are produced from no other source than the dead.
tgt_text.1436: But, if this is not the case, there will be need of other arguments.
tgt_text.1438: You must not, then," he continued, " consider this only with respect to men, if you wish to ascertain it with greater certainty, but also with respect to all animals and plants, and, in a word, with respect to every thing that is subject to gene­ ration, let us see whether they are not all so produced, no otherwise than 'contraries from contraries, wherever they have any such quality, as for instance the honourable is contrary to the base, and the just to the unjust, and so with ten thousand other things.
tgt_text.1439: 42. Let us consider this, then, whether it is necessary that all things which have a contrary should be produced from nothing else than their contrary.
tgt_text.1440: As for instance, -when any thing becomes greater is it not necessary • that, from being previously smaller, it afterwards became greater ?
tgt_text.1442: And if it becomes smaller, will it not, from being prc­ viously greater, afterwards become smaller ?”"
tgt_text.1447: if any thing becomes worse, must it not be­ come so from better ?
tgt_text.1448: and if more just, from more unjust ?”" How should it not ?""
tgt_text.1449: We have then," he said, " sufficiently determined this, that all things are thus produced, contraries from contraries ?”" Certainly."
tgt_text.1451: is there also something of this kind in them, for instance, between all two contraries a mutual twofold pro­ duction, from one to the other, and from that other back again ?
tgt_text.1452: for between a greater thing and a smaller there is increase and decrease, and do we not accordingly call the one to increase, the other to decrease ?
tgt_text.1454: And must not to be separated and commingled, to grow cold and to grow warm, and every thing in the same manner, even though sometimes we have not names to designate them, yet in fact be every where thus circumstanced of necessity, as to be produced from each other, and be subject to a reciprocal generation ?""
tgt_text.1456: "What then?" said Socrates, has life any contrary, as waking has its contrary, sleeping ?"" Certainly," he answered.
tgt_text.1458: Are not these, then, produced from each other, since they are contraries, and are not the modes by which they are pro­ duced twofold, intervening between these two ?""
tgt_text.1460: I then," continued Socrates, "will describe to you one pair of the contraries which I have just now mentioned, both what it is and its mode of production ;
tgt_text.1461: and do you describe to me the other.
tgt_text.1462: I say that one is to sleep, the other to awake;
tgt_text.1463: and from sleeping awaking is produced, and from awaking sleeping, and that the modes of their production are the one to fall asleep, the other to be roused.
tgt_text.1464: 44. Have I sufficiently explained this to you or not ?"" Certainly.""
tgt_text.1465: Do you then," he said, " describe to me, in the same manner, with respect to life and death ?
tgt_text.1466: Do you not say that life is contrary to death?""I do."" Yes.""
tgt_text.1467: And that they are produced from each other ?""
tgt_text.1468: What then, is produced from life ?
tgt_text.1470: What, then," said he, " is produced from death ?'"
tgt_text.1471: I must needs confess," he replied, " that life is.""
tgt_text.1472: From the dead, then, 0 Cebes, living things and living men, are produced.""
tgt_text.1474: "Our souls, therefore," said Socrates, " exist in Hades.""
tgt_text.1476: With respect, then, to their mode of production, is not one of them very clear ?
tgt_text.1477: for to die surely is clear ?
tgt_text.1478: is it not ?"" Certainly," he replied.
tgt_text.1479: "What then shall we do?" he continued;
tgt_text.1480: "shall we not find a corresponding contrary mode of production, or will na­ ture be defective in this ?
tgt_text.1481: Or must we discover a contrary mode of production to dying ?""
tgt_text.1483: What is this?"“ To revive.""Therefore," he proceeded, "if there is such a thing as to revive, will not this reviving be a mode of production from the dead to the living ?"" Certainly.""
tgt_text.1484: Thus, then, we have agreed, that the living are produced from the dead, no less than the dead from the living:
tgt_text.1485: but, this being the case, there appears to me sufficient proof that the souls of the dead must necessarily exist somewhere, from whence they are again produced.
tgt_text.1486: "45. " It appears to me, Socrates," he said, " that this must necessarily follow from what has been admitted.
tgt_text.1488: "See now, 0 Cebes," he said, " that we have not agreed on these things improperly, as it appears to me:
tgt_text.1489: for if one class of things were not constantly given back in the place of another, revolving as it were in a circle, but generation were direct from one thing alone into its opposite, and did not turn round again to the other, or retrace its course, do you know that all things would at length have the same form, be in the same state, and cease to be produced ?""
tgt_text.1491: "It is by no means difficult," he replied, " to understand what I mean;
tgt_text.1492: if, for instance, there should be such a thing as falling asleep, but no reciprocal waking again produced from a state of sleep, you know that at length all things would shew the fable of Endymion to be a jest, and it would be thought nothing at all of, because every thing else would be in the same state as him, namely, asleep.
tgt_text.1493: And if all things were mingled together, but never separated, that doctrine of Anaxagoras would soon be verified, . all things would be together.'
tgt_text.1494: 46. Likewise, my dear Cebes, if all things that partake of life should die, and after they are dead should remain in this state of death, and not revive again, would it not necessarily follow that at length all things should be dead, and nothing alive ?
tgt_text.1495: for if living beings are produced from other things, and living beings die, what could prevent their being all ab­ sorbed in death ?
tgt_text.1497: "Nothing whatever, I think, Socrates," replied Cebes, "but you appear to me to speak the exact truth.""For, Cebes," he continued, "as it seems to me, such un­ doubtedly is the case, and we have not admitted these things under a delusion, but it is in reality true that there is a reviv­ ing again, that the living are produced from the dead, that the souls of the dead exist, and that the condition of the good is better, and of the evil, worse.

"And indeed," said Cebes, interrupting him, " according to that doctrine, Socrates, which you are frequently in the habit of advancing, if it is true, that our learning is nothing else than reminiscence, according to this it is surely necessary that we must at some former time have learned what we now remem­ ber.

tgt_text.1500: so that from hence also the soul appears to be something immortal.""

tgt_text.1503: "48. " It is proved," said Cebes, "by one argument, and that a most beautiful one, that men, when questioned, if one ques­ tions them properly, of themselves describe all things as they are:
tgt_text.1504: however, if they had not innate knowledge and right reason, they would never be able to do this.
tgt_text.1505: Moreover, if one leads them to diagrams, or any thing else of the kind, it is then most clearly apparent that this is the case.""
tgt_text.1506: But if you are not persuaded in this way, Simmias," said Socrates, " see if you will agree with us on considering the mat­ ter thus.

tgt_text.1509: nevertheless, however, I should like to hear now how you would attempt to prove it.""
tgt_text.1510: I do it thus," he replied:
tgt_text.1511: " we admit surely that if any one be reminded of any thing, he must needs have known that thing at some time or other before.""

tgt_text.1517: the knowledge of a man is different from that of a lyre.""

tgt_text.1520: they both recognise the lyre, and receive in their minds the form of the person to whom the lyre belonged ?
tgt_text.1522: just as any one, seeing Simmias, is often reminded of Cebes, and so in an infinite num­ ber of similar instances.""
tgt_text.1523: An infinite number indeed, by Jupiter," said Simmias.“

Certainly.""
tgt_text.1526: And does it not also happen, that on seeing a picture of Simmias one is reminded of Simmias himself ?""
tgt_text.1528: Does it not happen, then, according to all this, that remi­ niscence arises partly from things like, and partly from things unlike ?"" It does.""
tgt_text.1529: But when one is reminded by things like, is it not neces­ sary that one should be thus further affected, so as to perceive whether, as regards likeness, this falls short or not of the thing of which one has been reminded ?""
tgt_text.1531: Consider, then," said Socrates, ., if the case is thus.
tgt_text.1532: Do we allow that there is such a thing as equality ?
tgt_text.1533: I do not mean of one log with another, nor one stone with another, nor any thing else of this kind, but something altogether different from all these, abstract equality;
tgt_text.1534: do we allow that there is any such thing or not ?""
tgt_text.1535: By Jupiter, we most assuredly do allow it," replied Sim­ mias.51. "
tgt_text.1536: And do we know what it is itself?""
tgt_text.1538: Whence have we derived the knowledge of it ?
tgt_text.1539: Is it not from the things we have just now mentioned, and that from seeing logs, or stones, or other things of the kind, equal, we have from these formed an idea of that which is different from these ?

tgt_text.1544: does abstract equality ever appear to you un­ equal ?
tgt_text.1545: or equality inequality ?"" Never, Socrates, at any time."“
tgt_text.1546: These equal things, then," he said, “ and abstract equality, are not the same ?"" By no means, Socrates, as it appears.""
tgt_text.1547: However, from these equal things," he said, " which are different from that abstract equality, have you not formed your idea and derived your knowledge of it ?""
tgt_text.1548: You speak most truly," he replied.
tgt_text.1549: If Is it not, therefore, from its being like or unlike them ?"" Certainly."
tgt_text.1550: "But it makes no difference," he said.
tgt_text.1551: "When, therefore, on seeing one thing, you form, from the sight of it, the notion of another, whether like or unlike, this," he said, " must ne­ cessarily be reminiscence.""
tgt_text.1552: Certainly."52. " What, then, as to this?" he continued;
tgt_text.1553: "are we af­ fected in any such way with regard to logs and the equal things we have just now spoken of?

tgt_text.2429: CALLICLES and Polus, two friends of Gorgias, the famous orator of Leontium in Sicily, happening to meet with Socrates and Chærephon, tell the former that he has sustained a great loss in not having been just now present when Gorgias was exhibiting his art.
tgt_text.2430: Chærephon admits that the fault is his, but adds that as Gorgias is his friend he can easily persuade him to exhibit to them either then, or at a future time.
tgt_text.2431: They accordingly, all four, adjourn to the house of Callicles, where Gorgias is staying.
tgt_text.2432: When arrived there, Chærephon, at the suggestion of Socrates, proposes to question Gorgias as to the art he professes ;
tgt_text.2433: but Polus, his pupil, somewhat impertinently offers to answer for him, on the ground that Gorgias is fatigued.
tgt_text.2434: Chærephon therefore asks, what is the art in which Gorgias is skilled, and what he ought to be called ?
tgt_text.2435: To which Polus answers, " the finest of the arts."
tgt_text.2436: Socrates, not satisfied with this, as being no answer at all, begs Gorgias himself to answer.
tgt_text.2437: He says, that rhetoric is the art he professes, and that he is a rhetorician, and able to make others rhetoriciansa.
tgt_text.2438: Socrates, having got Gorgias to promise that he would answer briefly, proceeds to ask him about what rhetoric is employed, and of what it is the science.
tgt_text.2439: Gorgias says, " of words," but Socrates shews, that other arts, in various degrees, make use of words, and that some, such as arithmetic and geometry, are altogether conversant with words;
tgt_text.2440: he therefore requests him to distinguish between these arts and rhetoric, and to explain about what particular thing these words are employed.
tgt_text.2441: Gor­ gias confidently answers, about " the greatest of all human concerns and the best."
tgt_text.2442: But'the physician, the teacher of gymnastics, the money-getter, in short all men, would say that the end which their own art aims at is the best;
tgt_text.2443: what then is this good which you say is the greatest good to men ?
tgt_text.2444: Gorgias answers, that it is the power of persuading by words.
tgt_text.2445: But Socrates objects that other arts do the same, for that every one who teaches any thing persuades what he teaches;
tgt_text.2446: you must therefore say of what kind of persuasion, and on what subject rhetoric is the art.
tgt_text.2447: It is that which is produced in courts of justice, and other public assemblies, and relates to matters that are just and unjust.
tgt_text.2448: But here again Socrates makes Gorgias admit, that there are two kinds of persuasion, one that pro­ duces belief without knowledge, the other that produces know­ ledge ;
tgt_text.2449: which of these two then does rhetoric produce ?
tgt_text.2451: But supposing the question is about the choice of physicians or shipwrights, or the building of walls, or the construction of ports or docks, will a rhetorician be con­ sulted, or a person skilled in these several matters ?
tgt_text.2452: Here Gorgias answers that on these and all other subjects a rhe­ torician will speak more persuasively than any other artist whatever:
tgt_text.2453: but it is his duty to use his art justly;
tgt_text.2454: though if he uses it unjustly, he and not his teacher is to blarneySocrates, here, perceiving an inconsistency in Gorgias' state­ ment, after deprecating his being offended at the course the dis­ cussion might take, asks whether by saying that a rhetorician can speak more persuasively to the multitude on any art, than a person skilled in that art, he does not mean the ignorant by the multitude;
tgt_text.2455: and, that being admitted, whether it does not follow that one who is ignorant will be more capable of per­ suading the ignorant, than one who possesses knowledge ?
tgt_text.2456: Gor­ gias allows this to be the case.
tgt_text.2457: Is the case, then, the same with respect to what is just and unjust, base and honourable, good and evil ?
tgt_text.2458: Can a rhetorician persuade the multitude on these, subjects, himself being ignorant of them, or must he know them before he learns rhetoric, or will the teacher of rhetoric instruct him in these ?
tgt_text.2459: Gorgias professes that if a pupil does not know these things he would learn them from him.
tgt_text.2460: But surely he who has learnt carpentering is a car­ penter, music a musician, medicine a physician;
tgt_text.2461: does it not follow then, that he who has learnt justice, must be just, and wish to do just actions ?
tgt_text.2463: and yet he had just now allowed that a rhetorician might make an unjust use of his art, and said, that in that case, the teacher ought not to be blamed, but the person who acts unjustly ought to be punishedc.
tgt_text.2464: At this point Polus takes up the discussion, and having elected to ask questions, instead of answering them, begins by asking Socrates what kind of art he considers rhetoric to be.
tgt_text.2465: Socrates answers that he does not think it is any art at all, but a kind of skill, employed for procuring gratification and pleasure :
tgt_text.2466: in other words, a species of flattery, of which there are many divisions.
tgt_text.2467: Polus asks what division it is.
tgt_text.2468: " Rhetoric, in my opinion," says Socrates, " is a semblance of a division of the political art," and as such is base.
tgt_text.2469: This answer, however, is not intelligible either to Gorgias or Polus ;
tgt_text.2470: at the request of the former, therefore, Socrates explains himself more clearly d.
tgt_text.2471: As there are two kinds of subject matter, he says, namely, soul and body, so there are two arts, that which relates to the soul is political;
tgt_text.2472: the other, relating to the body, he is not able to describe by one name, but there are two divisions of it, gymnastics and medicine.
tgt_text.2473: In the political art legislation cor­ responds to gymnastics, and the judicial art to medicine.
tgt_text.2474: But flattery, perceiving that these four take the best possible care of the soul and body respectively, has divided itself fourfold, and feigns itself to be what it pretends, not really caring for what is best, but seducing ignorance by means of pleasure.
tgt_text.2475: Thus cookery puts on the garb of medicine, and pretends that it knows the aliment best for the body;
tgt_text.2476: and again, personal decoration feigns itself to be gymnastics.
tgt_text.2477: Then, he adds, what personal decoration is to gymnastics, that is sophistry to legis­ lation, and what cookery is to medicine, that is rhetoric to jus­ tice;
tgt_text.2478: and so being proximate to each other, sophists and rhe­ toricians are confounded with legislators and judgese.
tgt_text.2479: Are good rhetoricians, then, asks Polus, to be esteemed as vile flatterers in cities ?
tgt_text.2480: Socrates replies that they appear to him to be of no estimation at all.
tgt_text.2481: But have they not the -greatest power in cities ?
tgt_text.2482: Not, if to have power is a good to him who possesses it.
tgt_text.2483: For what is it to have power ?
tgt_text.2484: is it to do what one wishes, or what appears to one to be best ?
tgt_text.2485: Polus admits that it is not good for a person devoid of under­ standing to do what appears to him to be best.
tgt_text.2486: He must therefore prove that rhetoricians possess understanding, other­ wise, since to have power is a good, they cannot do what they wish.
tgt_text.2487: Polus, however, is unable to distinguish between doing what one wishes and doing what appears to be best, and there­ fore agrees to change positions with Socrates, and to answer instead of asking questionsf.
tgt_text.2488: Socrates, then, asks, do men wish what they do for the sake of the thing itself, or for some other end ?
tgt_text.2489: for instance, do men take medicine because they wish to take it, or in order to health ?
tgt_text.2490: Again, do men incur the perils of the sea because they wish to be-in peril, or for the sake of riches ?
tgt_text.2491: Clearly the latter, in both and all similar cases.
tgt_text.2492: Now some things, such as wisdom, health, and riches, are good, but their contraries evil;
tgt_text.2493: but whatever we do, we do for the sake of that which is good.
tgt_text.2494: So that if we kill or banish a person, if it is good to do so, we wish it, and do what we wish;
tgt_text.2495: but if it is really evil, though it appears to us to be good, we do not what we wish.
tgt_text.2496: Polus sees the force of Socrates' argument, and can only ob­ ject to it that Socrates himself would like to do what he pleased, and would envy another whom he saw slaying, or spoiling, or imprisoning whom he pleased.
tgt_text.2497: But Socrates resolutely denies this, and insists that if he must necessarily either act unjustly or suffer unjustly, he should choose the latter;
tgt_text.2498: for that it is better to suffer than to commit injusticeg.

tgt_text.2501: and in order to do so mentions instances of men whom all have accounted happy, though they were unjust, especially that of Archelaus, king of Macedonia.
tgt_text.2502: But Socrates denies that any one who acts unjustly can be happy;
tgt_text.2503: and fur­ ther than this, he contends that a person who acts unjustly, and does not suffer punishment, is more miserable than one who meets with punishment for his injustice.
tgt_text.2504: To prove this he argues that it is more base to commit injustice than to suffer it, and if more base it must also be worse ;
tgt_text.2505: Polus admits the premise, but denies the conclusion.
tgt_text.2506: Socrates, therefore, endeavours to make his opponent admit this also by the fol­ lowing arguments.
tgt_text.2507: Beautiful things are esteemed beautiful, either on account of their usefulness, or the pleasure they oc­ casion, or both;
tgt_text.2508: and in like manner base things are deemed base on account of the pain or evil they occasion, or both;
tgt_text.2509: so that when of two things one is more beautiful than the other, it is so because it excels in pleasure or utility, or both;
tgt_text.2510: and when of two things one is more base, it must be because it exceeds in pain or evil.
tgt_text.2511: But Polus has already admitted that it is more base to commit injustice than to suffer it;
tgt_text.2512: it must therefore be so because it exceeds in pain or evil, or both.
tgt_text.2513: But to commit injustice does not exceed the suffering it, in pain;
tgt_text.2514: it remains, therefore, that it must exceed it in evil:
tgt_text.2515: consequently it must be worse, for whatever exceeds another thing in evil must necessarily be worseh.
tgt_text.2516: Having established his point thus far he now goes on to prove that it is the greatest of evils for one who has com­ mitted injustice not to be punished.
tgt_text.2517: To suffer punishment and to be justly chastised, are one and the same thing.
tgt_text.2518: But all just things are beautiful.
tgt_text.2519: Moreover wherever there is an agent there must also be a patient;
tgt_text.2520: and the patient suffers what the agent does;
tgt_text.2521: so that if the agent punishes justly the patient also suffers justly.
tgt_text.2522: But it has been just admitted that all just things are beautiful;
tgt_text.2523: and it was proved before that all beautiful things are good, either because they are pleasant or useful;
tgt_text.2524: whence it follows that he who is punished suffers that which is good, and is benefited in being freed from the greatest evil, which is depravity in the soul.
tgt_text.2525: From all this it is evident that rhetoric can be of no use whatever:
tgt_text.2526: for it is generally employed for the purpose of excusing injustice, and screening men from the punishment they deserve, which on the contrary they ought rather to court than to shun i.
tgt_text.2527: Polus having been thus completely silenced, Callicles takes up the argument and begins by asking whether Socrates is really in earnest.
tgt_text.2528: Finding that he is so, he blames Polus for having granted that it is more-base to commit injustice than to suffer it;

tgt_text.2530: whereas by nature it is more base to suffer injustice than to commit it.
tgt_text.2531: For the weak and the many make laws with a view to their own advantage, but nature herself avows that it is just that the better should have more than the worse, and the more powerful than the weaker.
tgt_text.2532: Callicles then pro­ ceeds to inveigh against philosophy and philosophers, and when he has done, Socrates, after having indulged in a vein of pleasant irony at his expense, returns to the subject, and asks what he means by the superior, the better, and the stronger, whether they are the same or different.
tgt_text.2533: Callicles says they are the same.

tgt_text.2538: Socrates, hereupon, asks whether they ought not to govern themselves also and be temperate, which elicits from Callicles the shameless avowal that a man should have as large desires as he can, and indulge them with­ out restraintk.
tgt_text.2539: Socrates having in vain endeavoured to persuade Callicles to change his opinion by two similitudes of a perforated cask, and a full and an empty one, to which he compares the soul, pro­ ceeds to combat his assertion that a happy life consists in having and indulging as large desires as possible.

tgt_text.2543: In order to confute this opinion, Socrates leads him to main­ tain that science and courage differ from each other and from the good;
tgt_text.2544: and then by a series of most subtle questions, too minute to be abbreviated, forces him to this absurd conclusion, that if the pleasant and the good are the same, a bad man, in­ asmuch as he oftentimes receives more pleasure than a good man, must be accounted better than a good one 1.

tgt_text.2548: is it from being the case that we do any thing merely for the sake of pleasure, that we pursue pleasure itself for the sake of the good m.

tgt_text.2660: Now, therefore, tell me in the same manner, what art Gorgias professes, and what we ought to call him.
tgt_text.2661: Or rather, Gorgias, do you tell us yourself what we ought to call you as skilled in what art.
tgt_text.2664: Socr. Ought we, then, to call you a rhetorician?
tgt_text.2666: And a good one, Socrates, if you wish to call me, as Homer says, what " I boast myself to be.
tgt_text.2670: Shall we say too that you are able to make others rhetoricians ?
tgt_text.2672: I profess this not only here but elsewhere.
tgt_text.2674: Are you willing then, Gorgias, to continue, as we are now doing, partly to ask questions and partly to answer, and to defer to some other occasion that prolixity of speech, such as Polus just now began with?
tgt_text.2675: But do not belie what you promised, but be willing to answer each question briefly.
tgt_text.2677: There are some answers, Socrates, which must neces.
tgt_text.2679: however, I will endeavour to make them as short as possible.
tgt_text.2680: For this is one of the things which I profess, that no one can say the same things in fewer words than me..8. Socr.
tgt_text.2681: There is need of this now, Gorgias;
tgt_text.2682: give me there­ fore a specimen of this very thing, conciseness of speech, and of prolixity at some other time.
tgt_text.2685: and you will admit that you never heard any one speak more concisely.
tgt_text.2687: Well then, since you say that you are skilled in the art of rhetoric, and that you can teach another this art, tell me about what is rhetoric employed?
tgt_text.2688: just as the art of weaving is employed in the making of garments, is it not so ?
tgt_text.2692: And is not music also employed in the composing of melodies ?
tgt_text.2695: Socr. By Juno, Gorgias, I admire your answers, for you answer as briefly as possible.
tgt_text.2697: I think, Socrates, that I do this well enough.
tgt_text.2701: Come then, answer me thus re­ specting rhetoric, of what is it the science ?
tgt_text.2706: Are they such as inform the sick by what kind of diet they may become well ?
tgt_text.2707: Gorg. No.Socr. Rhetoric, then, is not concerned with all kinds of words ?
tgt_text.2711: Yet it makes men able to speak?
tgt_text.2715: And does it not enable men to think on the same things on which it enables them to speak ?
tgt_text.2719: Does not, then, the medicinal art, of which we just now spoke, make men able to think and speak about the sick ?
tgt_text.2723: The medicinal art, then, as it appears, is conversant with words ?
tgt_text.2731: And is not the gymnastic art also conversant with words that relate to the good and bad habit of bodies ?
tgt_text.2734: And it is the same with other arts, Gorgias:
tgt_text.2735: each of them is conversant with those words that are employed about that particular thing of which each is the art.
tgt_text.2739: Why, then, do you not call other arts rhetorical, as being conversant with words, since you call that rhetoric which is employed about words ?
tgt_text.2741: Because, Socrates, almost the wholec science of other arts is conversant with manual operations and such-like ac­ tions;
tgt_text.2742: in rhetoric, however, there is no such manual operation, but all its activity and efficiency is by means of words.
tgt_text.2743: For this reason, I consider that the art of rhetoric is conversant with words, herein speaking correctly, as I affirm.
tgt_text.2745: Do I understand what kind of art you wish to call it ?
tgt_text.2746: but I shall soon comprehend it more clearly.
tgt_text.2748: We have arts, have we not?
tgt_text.2751: Of all the arts, some, I think, consist principally in workmanship, and stand in need of but few words, and others of none at all, but their work may be accomplished in silence, as painting, statuary, and many others.
tgt_text.2752: With such arts, you appear to me to say rhetoric has nothing to do ?
tgt_text.2755: You apprehend my meaning perfectly, Socrates.
tgt_text.2757: On the other hand, there are other arts which accom­ plish all by means of words, and require no work at all, or very little, such as theoretical d and practical arithmetic, geo­ metry, the game of dice, and many other arts;
tgt_text.2758: some of which require almost as many words as actions, and most of them more, so that altogether their whole activity and efficiency is by means of words.
tgt_text.2759: You appear to me to say that rhetoric is among arts of this kind.
tgt_text.2763: However, I do not think you mean to call any one of these rhetoric, although in the expression you used you so said, that rhetoric has its efficiency by means of words;
tgt_text.2764: and any who wished to catch at your words might reply, Do you say then, Gorgias, that arithmetic is rhetoric ?
tgt_text.2765: But I do not think that you call either arithmetic or geometry rhetoric.
tgt_text.2767: You think rightly, Socrates, and apprehend my mean­ ing correctly.
tgt_text.2768: Socr. Come then, complete the answer to my question.
tgt_text.2769: Since rhetoric is one of those arts which make great use of words, and there are others of the same kind, endeavour to tell me in reference to what, rhetoric has its efficiency in words.
tgt_text.2770: 13. Just as if any one should ask me respecting any of the arts which I but now mentioned:
tgt_text.2771: Socrates, what is the arith­ metical art ?
tgt_text.2772: I should say to him, as you did just now, That it is one of the arts that have their efficiency in words.
tgt_text.2773: And if he should further ask me, In reference to what?
tgt_text.2774: I should answer, In reference to the knowledge of even and odd, how many there may be of each.
tgt_text.2775: But if again he should ask me, What do you mean by the art of computation ?
tgt_text.2776: I should answer, that this also is one of those arts whose whole effici­ ency consists in words.
tgt_text.2777: And if he should further ask me, In reference to what ?
tgt_text.2778: I should answer, as they do who draw up motions in the assemblies of the people, That in other respects computation is the same as arithmetic, for it has reference to the same object, that is to say, the even and the odd;
tgt_text.2779: but it differs in this respect, that computation considers what rela­ tion even and odd have to themselves and to each other in regard to quantity.
tgt_text.2780: 14. And if any one should ask me about astronomy, and after I had said that its whole efficiency con­ sists in words, should say, But Socrates, to what do words employed about astronomy refer ?
tgt_text.2781: I should answer, That they are employed about the course of the stars, and of the sun and the moon, how they are related to each other with respect to velocity.
tgt_text.2783: And you would answer rightly, Socrates.
tgt_text.2785: Now then do you answer, Gorgias.
tgt_text.2786: For rhetoric is one of those arts which accomplish and effect every thing by means of words:
tgt_text.2791: Tell me then in reference to what?
tgt_text.2792: what is the par­ ticular thing about which these words are, which rhetoric uses?
tgt_text.2794: The greatest of all human concerns, Socrates, and the best.
tgt_text.2795: Socr. But, Gorgias, what you say is questionable, and by no means clear.
tgt_text.2796: For I think you must have heard at ban­ quets men singing that song in which the singers enumerate that the best thing is health, the second beauty, and the third, as the author of the song says, riches gained without fraud.
tgt_text.2799: but with what object do you men­ tion this?
tgt_text.2801: Because the artificers of those things which the author of the song has commended, namely, the physician, the master of gymnastics, and the money-getter, will forthwith present themselves, and the physician will say:
tgt_text.2803: For his art is not employed about the greatest good to men, but mine is.
tgt_text.2804: If, then, I should ask him, Who are you that say this?
tgt_text.2805: lie would probably answer, I am a physician.
tgt_text.2807: that the object of your art is the greatest good ?
tgt_text.2808: How can it be otherwise, Socrates, he would probably say, since its object is health?
tgt_text.2809: and what greater good can men have than health?
tgt_text.2810: And if after him again the master of gymnastics should say, I too should won­ der, Socrates, if Gorgias could shew you any greater good from his art than I can from mine, I should again say to him, And who are you, Sir, and what is your employment ?
tgt_text.2811: A master of gymnastics, he would say, and my employment is to make men beautiful and strong in their bodies.
tgt_text.2812: 16. After the mas­ ter of gymnastics, the money-getter would say, as I imagine, despising all others, Consider, I beg, Socrates, whether there is any greater good than riches, either with Gorgias, or any one else ?
tgt_text.2813: I should thereupon say to him, What, then, are you the artificer of this good ?
tgt_text.2818: Do you consider riches to be the greatest good to men?
tgt_text.2821: However, Gorgias here contends that his art is the cause of greater good than yours.
tgt_text.2822: It is clear then that after this he would ask,
tgt_text.2825: Come then, Gorgias, suppose that you are asked by them and by me, and answer, What is this, which you say is the greatest good to men, and of which you are the artificer ?
tgt_text.2827: That which is in reality, Socrates, the greatest good, and is at the same time the cause of liberty to men, and of their being able to rule over others in their several cities.
tgt_text.2829: What then do you say it is ?
tgt_text.2831: I say it is the power of persuading by words judges in a court of justice, senators in the senate-house, and the hearers in a public assembly, and in every other convention of a political nature.
tgt_text.2832: Moreover, by this power you will make the physician your slave, and the master of gymnastics your slave, and the money-getter will be found to have gained money, not for himself, but for another, for you who are able to speak, and persuade the multitude.
tgt_text.2834: At length you appear to me, Gorgias, to have shewn as nearly as possible what kind of art you consider rhetoric to be;
tgt_text.2835: and if I understand you rightly, you say that rhetoric is the artificer of persuasion, and that its whole employment and the sum of it terminates in this.
tgt_text.2836: Can you say that rhetoric has any further power than that of producing persuasion in the minds of the hearers ?
tgt_text.2839: but you appear to me to have defined it sufficiently.
tgt_text.2840: For that is the sum of it.
tgt_text.2842: Be assured that I, as I persuade myself, if there is any one, who in conversing with another, wishes to know the very thing about which the con­ versation is, be assured, I say, that I am such a person;
tgt_text.2843: and I think that you are too.
tgt_text.2848: The persuasion which you speak of as resulting from rhetoric, what it is, and with what particu­ lars it is conversant, be assured I do not clearly understand, not but that I have a suspicion of what I suppose you mean, and about what it is employed:
tgt_text.2849: yet I will not the less ask you what persuasion you mean results from rhetoric, and with what particulars it is conversant.
tgt_text.2850: Why then do I who have a sus­ picion ask you, and not rather myself speak?
tgt_text.2851: Not on your account, but on account of the discussion, that it may proceed in such a manner as to make the subject of the discussion most clear to us.
tgt_text.2852: 19. For consider whether I seem to you right in putting the question to you:
tgt_text.2853: just as if I should ask you what kind of a painter is Zeuxis ?
tgt_text.2854: if you were to tell me that he paints animals, might I not justly enquire of you, what kind of animals he paints ?
tgt_text.2859: And would it not be for this reason, because there are also other painters who paint many other animals ?
tgt_text.2863: But if no one else but Zeuxis painted them, you would have answered properly.
tgt_text.2867: Come then, with respect to rhetoric, tell me, whether it appears to you that rhetoric alone produces persuasion, or do other arts produce it likewise ?
tgt_text.2869: Does he who teaches any thing persuade what he teaches, or not ?
tgt_text.2873: Again, if we speak of the same arts of which we just now made mention, does not arithmetic teach us such things as relate to number ?
tgt_text.2874: and does not an arithmetician the same ?
tgt_text.2878: Gorg. Yes.Socr. Arithmetic, then, is an artificer of persuasion.
tgt_text.2882: If, then, any one should ask us,
tgt_text.2883: What persuasion it produces, and with respect to what?
tgt_text.2885: That which teaches about the quantity of even and odd.
tgt_text.2886: In like manner we may shew, that all the other arts of which we spoke just now, produce persuasion, and what kind of persuasion, and with respect to what:
tgt_text.2890: Socr. Rhetoric then, is not alone an artificer of persuasion.
tgt_text.2894: Since then, it does not alone produce this effect, but other arts do the same, we may justly, as in the case of the painter, next enquire of the speaker;
tgt_text.2895: of what kind of persua­ sion, and of persuasion on what subject rhetoric is the art?
tgt_text.2896: Does it not appear to you that this question may fairly be asked ?
tgt_text.2899: Socr. Answer then, Gorgias, since this appears to you to be the case.
tgt_text.2901: I speak then, Socrates, of that persuasion which is produced in courts of justice, and in other public assemblies, as I just now mentioned, and with respect to matters that are just and unjust.
tgt_text.2903: I suspected, Gorgias, that you meant that persuasion, and on such matters.
tgt_text.2904: But do not be surprised if I shortly ask you a question that may appear to be evident, but which I shall notwithstanding repeat, for, as I before observed, I ask it for the sake of carrying on the discussion in an orderly manner, and not on your account, but that we may not be in the habit of catching up each other's words on suspicion;
tgt_text.2905: but do you finish what you have to say according to your own plan, just as you please.
tgt_text.2907: You appear to me to act rightly, Socrates.
tgt_text.2909: Come then, let us examine this too.
tgt_text.2910: Do you admit that to learn is any thing ?
tgt_text.2917: Whether, therefore, does it appear to you, that to learn and to believe, and learning and belief are the same, or different ?
tgt_text.2919: I think, Socrates, that they are different.
tgt_text.2922: and you may know from this;
tgt_text.2923: if any one should ask you, Is there, Gorgias, a false and true belief?
tgt_text.2924: I think you would say there is.
tgt_text.2928: Well then, is there a false and true science?
tgt_text.2932: It is clear, therefore, that they (belief and science) are not the same.
tgt_text.2936: Yet both those who learn are persuaded, and those who believe.
tgt_text.2940: Are you willing, therefore, that we lay down two kinds of persuasion, one that produces belief without knowledge, but the other science ?
tgt_text.2944: Which kind of persuasion, then, does rhetoric pro­ duce in courts of justice and other public assemblies, re­ specting what is just and unjust?
tgt_text.2945: is it that from which belief springs without knowledge, or that from which knowledge arises ?
tgt_text.2947: It is evident, Socrates, that it is that from which belief springs.
tgt_text.2948: Socr. Rhetoric then, as it seems, Gorgias, is the artificer of a persuasion which produces belief, and not of that which teaches respecting the just and unjust.
tgt_text.2952: A rhetorician, therefore, does not profess to teach courts of justice and other public assemblies, respecting things just and unjust, but only to produce belief.
tgt_text.2953: For surely he could not teach so great a multitude in a short time things of such great importance.
tgt_text.2955: Certainly not.23. Socr. Come then, let us see now what we ought to say of rhetoric.
tgt_text.2956: For I, indeed, am not yet able to understand what I should say.
tgt_text.2957: When an assembly is held in a city, for the choice of physicians, or shipwrights, or any other kind of arti­ ficer, is it not the case that the rhetorician will refrain from giving his advice ?
tgt_text.2958: for it is evident that, in each election, the most skilful artist ought to be chosen.
tgt_text.2959: Nor will he be con­ sulted when the question is respecting the building of walls, or the construction of ports or docks, but architects only.
tgt_text.2960: Nor, again, when a deliberation occurs respecting the choice of generals, or the marshalling an army against enemies, or the occupation of posts,-but on such occasions those who are skilled in military affairs will give advice, and not rheto­ ricians.
tgt_text.2961: What do you say, Gorgias, on such points?
tgt_text.2962: For since you say that you are a rhetorician, and are able to make others rhetoricians, it is proper to enquire of you what are the things about which your art is concerned.
tgt_text.2963: And consider that I am labouring for your benefit.
tgt_text.2964: For, perhaps, some one who is now within the house may wish to become your disciple;
tgt_text.2965: for I perceive some, nay several, who probably are ashamed to question you.
tgt_text.2966: 24. In being questioned, therefore, by me, con­ sider yourself to be questioned by them, What would be the consequence to us, Gorgias, if we should put ourselves under your instructions ?
tgt_text.2967: On what subjects shall we be able to give advice to the city?
tgt_text.2968: Whether about the just only and the un­ just;
tgt_text.2969: or on those subjects of which Socrates just now made mention ?
tgt_text.2972: I will endeavour, Socrates, to develope clearly the whole power of rhetoric:
tgt_text.2973: for you have admirably led the way.
tgt_text.2974: You doubtless know that these docks and walls of the Athenians, and the structure of the ports, were made partly on the advice of Themistocles, and partly on that of Pericles, but not of artificers.
tgt_text.2976: This is told of Themistocles, Gorgias:
tgt_text.2977: and I myself heard Pericles when he .
tgt_text.2978: gave us his advice respecting the middle wall f.Gorg.
tgt_text.2979: And when there is an election of any such persons as you mentioned, Socrates, you see that the rhetoricians are the persons who give advice, and whose opinion prevails in such matters.
tgt_text.2981: It is because I wonder at this, Gorgias, that I have been for some time asking you, what is the power of rhetoric.
tgt_text.2982: For when I consider it in this manner, it appears to me almost divine in its magnitude.
tgt_text.2984: If you knew all, Socrates, that it comprehends under itself almost all powers!
tgt_text.2985: And I will give you a strong proof of this.
tgt_text.2986: For I have often, ere now, gone with my brother and other physicians to various sick persons, who would neither drink their medicine, nor suffer themselves to be cut or cau­ terized by the physician, and when the physician was unable to persuade them, I have done so by no other art than rhetoric.
tgt_text.2987: I say too, that if a rhetorician and a physician should go to any city you please, and it were necessary to contend by argument in a general assembly, or any other convention, which should be chosen, a rhetorician or a physician, the physician would be held in no account, but he that has the power of speaking would be chosen, if he pleased.
tgt_text.2988: 26. And if he should con­ tend with any other artist whatever, the rhetorician would persuade that he himself should be chosen in preference to any one else.
tgt_text.2989: For there is no subject on which a rhetorician will not speak to the multitude more persuasively than any other artist whatever.
tgt_text.2990: Such, then, and so great is the power of this art.
tgt_text.2991: It is right however, Socrates, to use rhetoric in the same way as any other exercise employed in contests:
tgt_text.2992: for it is not right to use other exercises against all men alike ;
tgt_text.2993: nor, because any one has learnt pugilism, and the pancratium, and to fight with arms, so as to be superior both to friends and enemies, is it therefore proper to strike, or pierce, or slay one's friends.
tgt_text.2994: 27. Nor, by Jupiter, if some one who, by hav­ ing frequented the palæstra, has made his body robust, and become a pugilist, should afterwards strike his father or mother, or any other of his relatives or friends, would it on that account be proper to hate, and expel from cities, the training masters and those who teach how to fight with arms.
tgt_text.2995: For they instructed their pupils in these exercises, in order that they might make a proper use of them against enemies, and those that do wrong, for self-defence, and not for attack;
tgt_text.2996: but they contrariwise, use their strength and skill improperly.
tgt_text.2997: The teachers, therefore, are not wicked, nor is their art either to be blamed, or for this reason wicked, but they, I think, who do not use it properly.
tgt_text.2998: 28. The same may be said of rhetoric.
tgt_text.2999: For a rhetorician is able to speak against all men, and on every subject;
tgt_text.3000: so that he can best persuade the multitude, in a word, on whatever subject he pleases:
tgt_text.3001: but he ought not any the more on this account to detract from the reputation of phy­ sicians, because he is able to do it, nor of other artificers;
tgt_text.3002: but he should use rhetoric justly, as well as other exercises.
tgt_text.3003: In my opinion, however, if any one having become a rhetorician abuses this power and art, it is not proper to hate the teacher and expel him from cities, for he imparted the knowledge of it for just purposes, but the other makes a contrary use of it.
tgt_text.3004: It is just, therefore, to hate, banish, and slay him who does not make a right use of it, but not the teacher.
tgt_text.3006: I think, Gorgias, that you as well as I, have been present at many discussions, and that you have observed this in them, that it is not easy for men, on whatever subject they I undertake to converse, having propounded their ideas to each other, both learning themselves and teaching one another, then I to put an end to the conference;
tgt_text.3007: but if they have a contro­ versy about any thing, and one says that the other does not speak correctly or clearly, they are indignant, and each thinks that the other is speaking out of envy, from a love of conten­ tion, and not seeking what was proposed in the discussion:
tgt_text.3008: and some, at length g, depart in a most disgraceful manner, having h reviled each other, and spoken and heard such things that even the bystanders are vexed at themselves for having deigned to listen to such men.
tgt_text.3009: 30. But why do I say this ?
tgt_text.3010: Because you now appear to me to say what does not follow from, or accord with, what you first said respecting rhetoric.
tgt_text.3011: I am afraid, therefore, to proceed with my refuta­ tion, lest you should suppose that I do not speak with zeal for the subject, that it may be made clear, but out of opposition to you.
tgt_text.3012: If, then, you are of that class of men to which I be­ long, I should gladly question you:
tgt_text.3013: but if not, I would forbear to do so.
tgt_text.3014: But to what class of men do I belong ?
tgt_text.3015: To those who are willingly refuted, if they say any thing that is not true, and who willingly refute if any one says any thing that is not true ;
tgt_text.3016: and who are not less pleased to be refuted than to refute.
tgt_text.3017: For I consider the former to be the greater good, inasmuch as it is a greater good one's-self to be delivered from the greatest evil than to deliver another.
tgt_text.3018: For I think no evil so great to man as false opinion on the subjects we are now discussing.
tgt_text.3019: If, then, you say that you are such a man, let us continue our discussion;
tgt_text.3020: [31.] but if you think we ought to desist, let us give it up, and put an end to the argument.
tgt_text.3022: But indeed, Socrates, I profess myself to be such a man as you describe.
