tgt_text.7073: PHÆDRUS, whom we have already3 met with among the fol­ lowers of the sophist Hippias, happening to meet with Socrates, tells him that he has just left the orator Lysias, who had writ­ ten and recited a speech on the subject of love, in which he argued that a youth ought rather to shew favour to one who is not in love than to one who is.
tgt_text.7074: Socrates, who pretends to be very anxious to hear the speech, begs Phaedrus to repeat it from memory as well as he is able, for he cannot doubt but that he has learnt it by heart, so great is his admiration for its author.
tgt_text.7075: Phaedrus affects shyness, though in reality desirous of practising himself on Socrates:
tgt_text.7076: at length, however, Socrates discovers that he has a copy of it under his cloak, so they pro­ ceed on their walk, talking by the way, till they reach a plane- tree on the banks of the Ilissus, outside the walls of Athens, under whose ample shade they lie downb.
tgt_text.7077: Phædrus reads the speech, which in addition to the faults of obscurity, inconclusiveness, and tautology, takes a very low and sensual view of the passion of love c.
tgt_text.7078: When it is ended, Phædrus asks Socrates what he thinks of it, and whether it is not a wonderful composition, especially as to the language.
tgt_text.7079: Socrates at first praises it ironically, but on being pressed by Phædrus points out some of its faults, and says that even Lysias himself could not be satisfied with it, and that many others have both spoken and written finer things on the same subject, with which at that very instant his breast is full.
tgt_text.7080: Phæ­ drus catches at this, and insists on Socrates repeating these fine things, promising that if he says any thing that excels the speech of Lysias he will erect his statue in gold in Olympiad.
tgt_text.7081: As it is the present design of Socrates to take the same low view of love that Lysias had done, he determines to speak with his face covered, that he may not falter through shame.
tgt_text.7082: He begins by a definition of love, which he represents to be desire hurried on to the pleasure derived from personal beauty;
tgt_text.7083: and then he goes on to shew, with great perspicuity, how a person under the influence of such a passion must needs be anxious that the beloved object should not excel himself or be admired by others.
tgt_text.7084: Then with regard to the body, he will wish to make it effeminate, and be anxious that his beloved should be as much as possible dependent on him;
tgt_text.7085: and at length he will become unfaithful, forget all his former vows and promises, and leave his favourite despised and destitute, who will suffer most of all in this, that he has been debarred from cultivating his soul, than which, he adds, there neither is nor ever will be any thing more precious in the sight of gods and men e.Phædrus expects that Socrates will not only shew the dis­ advantages of granting favours to a lover, but also go on to point out the advantages of granting them to one who is not in love.
tgt_text.7086: This, however, he refuses to do;
tgt_text.7087: and then, conscience- stricken for that he has been guilty of an offence against the deity of Love in speaking of him in so impious a manner, he determines on making his recantation, by uttering a speech which shall describe that deity in his true character.
tgt_text.7088: He be­ gins by condemning his former assertion that favour ought rather to be shewn to one who is not in love than to a lover, be­ cause the latter is mad and the former in his sober senses.
tgt_text.7089: For, he argues, it is not universally true that madness is an evil, so far from it, that the greatest blessings spring from madness, for even prophetic inspiration is a species of madness and de­ rives its very name from it.
tgt_text.7090: And love is one of many kinds of madness, and as such the source of the greatest happiness to man.
tgt_text.7091: To prove this, he says, it is necessary to examine into the nature of the soul, both human and divine.
tgt_text.7092: The soul, then, is immortal, because it contains the principle of motion within itself (a subtle argument which it may be observed was not adduced in the Phædo, where the soul's immortality was the immediate point under discussion.)
tgt_text.7093: Still, to explain what the soul is would require a divine and lengthened exposition ;
tgt_text.7094: he must therefore content himself with saying what it is like.
tgt_text.7095: He therefore compares the soul to a pair of winged steeds and a charioteer.
tgt_text.7096: The horses and charioteers of the gods are all good, but all others are mixed.
tgt_text.7097: While the soul is perfect and winged it soars aloft, but when it loses its wings it is borne downward and becomes united with a body in which it takes up its abode, and the two united are called mortal.
tgt_text.7098: He then describes how Jupiter goes first, driving a winged chariot, and is followed by a host of gods and demons distributed into eleven divisions :
tgt_text.7099: in their flight they reach the external regions of heaven, and behold truth, justice, temperance, science, in their essences.
tgt_text.7100: Other inferior souls endeavour to follow and imitate them;
tgt_text.7102: those that get a glimpse of any of the true essences are free from harm till the next revolution, but those that are unable to do so are weighed down and lose their wings, and become implanted in earthly natures of various orders, and then, according to their conduct in this condition, are either restored to their former state or still further degraded.
tgt_text.7103: The mind of the philosopher, however, is alone furnished with wings, because his memory dwells on that which is divined
tgt_text.7104: This then is the madness above spoken of, when one, behold­ ing beauty in this lower world, is reminded of the true, and looking upwards to it despises things below and is deemed to be affected with madness.
tgt_text.7105: But he who has become corrupted is not easily carried hence to beauty itself, nor does he reve­ rence it when he beholds it, but looks upon it with carnal sensuality;
tgt_text.7106: whereas he, who has not been so far corrupted, when he beholds the imitation of beauty here, reverences it as a god, and, but for the imputation of madness, would sacrifice to it.
tgt_text.7107: Then his wings begin to swell again and en­ deavour to burst forth anew;
tgt_text.7108: but when separated from the beautiful object the soul becomes parched and the passages through which the wings shoot forth become closed.
tgt_text.7109: Thus alternately tormented with agony and joy, it becomes frantic and runs about trying to see the possessor of the beauty.
tgt_text.7111: Now when a follower of Jupiter is thus seized, he is better able to bear the burden of the winged god:
tgt_text.7112: for such a one seeks one who resembles Jupiter to be the object of his love;
tgt_text.7113: and when he has found him, he en­ deavours to make him like his own gods.
tgt_text.7114: As each soul was before divided into three parts, two having the form of horses, and the third that of a charioteer, so that division must still be maintained.
tgt_text.7115: When therefore the cha­ rioteer beholds the love-inspiring sight, the obedient horse is easily restrained, but the other compels them to hurry to the favourite, and longs to indulge in the delights of love.
tgt_text.7116: But the charioteer, on approaching him, is carried back to absolute beauty, and being awe-struck falls backward and throws the horses on their haunches.
tgt_text.7117: When by being repeatedly checked in this way the vicious horse has laid aside his insolence, he becomes humbled and the soul of the lover follows his favourite with reverence and awe.
tgt_text.7118: And the beloved being worshipped by one who does not feign the passion but who really feels it, re­ quites the affection of his worshipper, and in turn longs for the lover in the same manner that he is longed for, possessing love's image;
tgt_text.7120: If then the better parts of their mind prevail so as to lead to a well-regulated life and philo­ sophy, they pass their life in bliss and concord, and when they depart this life, they become winged and win one of the three truly Olympic contests, a greater good than which neither human prudence nor divine madness can bestow on man.
tgt_text.7121: If however, they have adopted a coarser and less philosophic mode of life, but still honourable, in the end they find the body without wings indeed, yet making an effort to become winged and so carry off no trifling prize of impassioned madness h.
tgt_text.7122: When Socrates had ended his recantation to Love, Phsedrus expresses great admiration of his speech ;
tgt_text.7123: and adds that he doubts whether Lysias will ever venture to write speeches again.
tgt_text.7124: But Socrates shews him that such an expectation is altogether groundless;
tgt_text.7125: and after a charming little episode on the origin of grasshoppers, proposes to consider in what a correct mode of speaking and writing consists
tgt_text.7126: The first essential is that the speaker should know the truth of the subject on which he is about to speak.
tgt_text.7127: And though it is commonly said that an orator need not know what is really just, but only what will appear so to the multitude, yet Socrates with great force destroys this fallacy, and shews that such rhetoric is not an art but an inartistic trick;
tgt_text.7128: for a genuine art of speaking neither does nor can exist without laying hold of truth.
tgt_text.7129: Rhetoric must be an art that leads the soul by means of argument.
tgt_text.7130: Now in courts of justice and popular assemblies men succeed by making things appear similar to each other so far as they are capable of being made appear so;
tgt_text.7131: and deception will more frequently occur in things that nearly resemble each other, so that a person who means to persuade or deceive another must be able to distinguish ac­ curately the similarity and dissimilarity of things, and so lead his hearer by means of resemblances.
tgt_text.7132: Taking this as his principle, Socrates proceeds to shew that the speech of Lysias is altogether inartistic, for that he ought first of all to have defined Love and divided it into its different species and shewn of which class he was going to speak, whereas he begins where he should have ended, and throughout speaks at random with­ out any definite design.
tgt_text.7133: He then proceeds to comment on his own two speeches.
tgt_text.7134: In one he argued that favour ought to be shewn to one that is in love, in the other to a person that is not in love.
tgt_text.7135: In one he said that love was a kind of divine madness, and then dividing this madness into four parts he shewed that the madness of Love is the best.
tgt_text.7136: In these speeches, then, are seen the two methods of arguing correctly, definition and division, the former of which contemplates many things under one aspect and brings them together under one general idea, the latter separates that general idea into speciesk.
tgt_text.7137: Socrates then ridicules the rules of rhetoric laid down by many of the sophists, and having passed a high eulogium on Pericles, shews that a perfect orator must know the real nature of the things to which he will have to apply his speeches, and that is the soul;
tgt_text.7138: for as the power of speech consists in leading the soul, he must know how many kinds of soul there are, and by what arguments each kind is most easily persuaded1.
tgt_text.7139: From speaking he proceeds to writing, and tells a pleasant story of the invention of letters, and remarks that the evil of writing is, that, like painting, if you ask it a question it cannot answer;

tgt_text.7141: But there is another kind of discourse far more excellent, which is written in the learner's mind, and knows when to speak and when to be silent.
tgt_text.7142: The conclusion of the whole is that a speaker should be acquainted with the true nature of each subject on which he speaks or writes, be able to define, and divide things into their species until he reaches the indivisible, and to inves­ tigate the nature of the soul and apply his discourses to each soul according to its capacity.

tgt_text.7674: and this is a law of Adrastiai, that whatever soul, in accompanying a deity, has beheld any of the true essences, it shall be free from harm until the next revolution, and if it can always accomplish this, it shall be always free from harm :

tgt_text.7751: As in the beginning of this account I divided each soul into three parts, two of them having the form of horses, and the third that of a charioteer, so let us still maintain that division:

tgt_text.7753: what however is the virtue of the good one, or the vice of the bad one, we have not yet explained, but must now declare.
tgt_text.7754: That one of them, then, which is in the nobler condition, is in form erect, finely-moulded, high-necked, hook-nosed, white- coloured, black-eyed, a lover of honour, with temperance and modesty, and a companion of true glory, without the whip is driven by word of command and voice only:
tgt_text.7755: the other, on the other hand, is crooked, thick set, clumsily put together, strong- necked, short-throated, flat-faced, black-coloured, gray-eyed, hot-blooded, a companion of insolence and swaggering, shaggy about the ears, deaf, scarcely obedient to whip and spur toge­ ther.

tgt_text.10586: but if we shall continue still in­ volved in difficulties, we must humble ourselves, I imagine, and give ourselves up to discussion, like those who are sea­ sick, to be trampled on and treated as it pleases.
tgt_text.10587: Hear, then, how I still find a way out of our enquiry.
tgt_text.10592: I shall deny that we made a correct admission, when we admitted that it is impossible for a person to judge that what he knows is what he does not know and be thus de­ ceived ;
tgt_text.10593: but in some respect it is possible.
tgt_text.10595: Do you mean that which I suspected at the time when we said this, might be the case, that sometimes I know­ ing Socrates, and seeing another person at a distance whom I do not know, have thought it was Socrates, whom I do know ?
tgt_text.10596: For what you mention happens in a case of this kind.
tgt_text.10598: Are we not, then, driven from that position, because it made us, while we know, not know the things that we do know ?
tgt_text.10602: Let us not, then, make our assumption in this way but as follows;
tgt_text.10603: and perhaps it will in some respect succeed for us, and perhaps it will oppose us.
tgt_text.10604: For we are in a condition in which it is necessary to examine our whole argument in every point of view.
tgt_text.10605: Consider, therefore, whether I say any thing to the purpose.
tgt_text.10606: Is it possible for a person who did not know something before, afterwards to learn it ?
tgt_text.10610: And can he not also learn another thing after another ?
tgt_text.10614: Suppose, then, I beg, for the sake of argument, that we have in our souls a waxen tablet, in one larger, in an­ other smaller, in one of purer wax, in another of impurer, in some of harder, and in others again of softer, but in some of a moderate quality.
tgt_text.10618: Let us say, then, that this is a gift of Mnemosyne the mother of the Muses ;
tgt_text.10619: and that, whatever we wish to remember of things that we have seen, or heard, or have ourselves thought of, we impress in this, by placing it under our perceptions and thoughts, as if we were taking off the impressions from rings:
tgt_text.10620: and that whatever is imprinted, this we remember and know, as long as its image remains;
tgt_text.10621: but when it is effaced, or can be no longer imprinted, we forget and do not know it.
tgt_text.10625: When, therefore, a person knows these things and considers any of the things that he sees or hears, consider whether in this way he can judge falsely ?
tgt_text.10629: By thinking with respect to what he knows, that they i are at one time the things that he knows, and at another the things that he does not know.
tgt_text.10630: For in a former part of our discussion we made an improper admission in admitting that this was impossible.
tgt_text.10633: But how do you mean now ?
tgt_text.10635: We must speak thus on this subject, defining it from the beginning:
tgt_text.10636: It is impossible that he who knows any thing, and has a remembrance of it in his soul, but does not actually perceive it, can think that it is some other thing that he knows, of which he has the impression, though he does not perceive it:
tgt_text.10637: and again, it is impossible that any one can think that what he knows is that which he does not know, and of which he has not the seal:
tgt_text.10638: or that what he does not know is that which he does not know:
tgt_text.10639: or that what he does not know is that which he does know:
tgt_text.10640: or think that what he perceives is some other thing that he perceives:
tgt_text.10641: or that what he perceives is something that he does not perceive :
tgt_text.10642: or that what he does not perceive is some other thing that he does not perceive :
tgt_text.10643: or that what he does not perceive is something that he docs perceive.
tgt_text.10644: And again it is still more impossible, if that can be, that a person should think that what he knows and perceives, and of which he has an impression by means of perception, is some­ thing else that he knows and perceives, and of which in like manner he has an impression by means of perception.
tgt_text.10645: And it is impossible that what he knows and perceives, and of which he has a correct remembrance, he can think is something else that he knows :
tgt_text.10646: or that what he knows and perceives, and in like manner retains in his remembrance, is something else that he perceives:
tgt_text.10647: or again, that what he neither knows nor per­ ceives is something else that he neither knows nor perceives:
tgt_text.10648: or that what he neither knows nor perceives is something else that he does not know;
tgt_text.10649: or that what he neither knows nor perceives is something else that he does not perceive.
tgt_text.10650: In all these cases it is utterly impossible for any one to judge falsely.
tgt_text.10651: It remains, therefore, that it must take place, if anywhere, in the following cases.
tgt_text.10655: perhaps I shall understand you better from them ;
tgt_text.10656: for at present I do not follow you.

tgt_text.10659: or from those which he does not know, but perceives;
tgt_text.10660: or that the things which he knows and perceives are some of the things which he likewise knows and perceives.
tgt_text.10662: Now I am left much further behind than I was.

tgt_text.10678: Do I say any thing to the purpose or not ?
tgt_text.10682: This then was the first of the cases that I mentioned.
tgt_text.10686: But the second was this, that I knowing one of you, but not knowing the other, and perceiving neither, should never think that he whom I know is the person whom I do not know.
tgt_text.10690: The third was this, that I neither knowing nor per­ ceiving either of them, should not think that he whom I do' not know is some other person of those whom I do not know:
tgt_text.10691: and consider that you again hear in succession all the instances before put, in which I shall never form a false judgment re­ specting you and Theodorus, neither while knowing nor igno­ rant of you both, nor while knowing one, and not the other;
tgt_text.10692: and in the same way with regard to perceptions, if you follow me.
tgt_text.10697: It remains, therefore, that I may form a false judg­ ment in this case, when knowing you and Theodorus, and hav­ ing the impression of both of you in that waxen tablet made by a seal ring as it were, seeing you both from a distance and not sufficiently distinguishing you, I endeavour, by attributing the peculiar impression of each to his peculiar aspect, applying it so as to adapt it to its own form in order that I may recognise it, then failing in this, and changing them like those that put their shoes on the wrong feet, I fit the aspect of each to the impression of the other, as happens in looking into mirrors, where the sight passes from the right to the left, so I fall into the same error;
tgt_text.10698: then mistaken opinion and false judgment take place.
tgt_text.10700: What happens with regard to judgment, Socrates, seems wonderfully like what you describe.
tgt_text.10702: Still further, when, knowing both of you, in addition to knowing I perceive one, but not the other, I have a know- ledge of the other not according to perception, which I thus described before, but you did not then understand me.
tgt_text.10707: I said this however, that a person who knows and perceives one and has a knowledge of him according to perception, will never think that he is some other person whom he knows and perceives, and of whom he has a know­ ledge according to perception.
tgt_text.10708: Was not this what I said?
tgt_text.10712: There remained then the case that was just now mentioned, in which we said that false judgment takes place, when a person knowing you both and seeing you both, or having some other perception of you both, has not the im­ pression of each according to the perception of each, but, like an unskilful archer, shoots beside the mark and misses, this then is called a falsehood.
tgt_text.10716: When, therefore, perception is present to one of the impressions, and not to the other, and the one applies the im­ pression of the absent perception to that which is present, in this case the mind is 'altogether deceived:
tgt_text.10717: and, in a word, with respect to things that a person has neither known nor ever per­ ceived, it is not possible, as it seems, either to be deceived, or to form a false judgment, if there is any soundness in what we now say:
tgt_text.10718: but with respect to things that we know and perceive, in these very things judgment is conversant and turns round, becoming both false and true, by collecting together in a direct and straight line the copies and marks proper to each, it is true, but sideways and obliquely, false.
tgt_text.10721: Is it not well described, Socrates ?
tgt_text.10723: You will say so still more, when you hear what follows.
tgt_text.10724: For to judge truly is beautiful, but to be deceived is base.
tgt_text.10728: They say, then, that these things proceed from hence.
tgt_text.10729: When the wax in any one's soul is deep, abundant, smooth, and properly moulded, objects entering by means of the percep­ tions and impressing themselves on this heart r of the soul, as Homer calls it, obscurely intimating its resemblance to wax, then pure and sufficiently deep impressions being made in these, become lasting, and such men are.
tgt_text.10730: first of all easily taught, next have retentive memories, and lastly do not change the impressions of the perceptions, but form true judgments;
tgt_text.10731: for, as these impressions are clear, and in a wide space, they quickly distribute to their proper images each of the things that are called beings.;
tgt_text.10732: and such men are called wise.
tgt_text.10733: Does it not appear so to you ?
tgt_text.10737: When, therefore, any one's heart is covered with hair, which the very wise poet has celebrated, or when it is muddy, and not of pure wax, or very soft, or hard, those in whom it is soft are easily taught, but are forgetful, and those in whom it is hard, the contrary;
tgt_text.10738: but those who have it hairy and rough, and stony or full of earth or mixed mud, have indistinct im­ pressions ;
tgt_text.10739: they are also indistinct in those that are hard, for there is no depth in them;
tgt_text.10740: they are likewise indistinct in those that are soft, for by being confused they soon become obscure ;
tgt_text.10741: but if, in addition to all this, they fall one upon another by reason of narrowness of space, if any one's soul is little, they are still more indistinct than the others.
tgt_text.10742: All these, therefore, are such as form false judgments.
tgt_text.10743: For when they see, or hear, or think about any thing, not being able at once to attribute each object to its impression, they are slow, and attributing different objects to different impressions, they for the most part see wrongly, and hear wrongly, and think wrongly;
tgt_text.10744: and these are said to be deceived in objects and ignorant.
tgt_text.10746: You speak as correctly as man can do, Socrates.

tgt_text.10828: But, Theætetus, our conversation has been all along full of defects.
tgt_text.10829: For we have over and over again used the expressions, We know, and We do not know, We have a scientific knowledge, and We have not a scientific knowledge, as if we both of us understood something about it, whereas we are still ignorant of what science is.

tgt_text.10832: But how will you converse, Socrates, if you abstain from the use of these expressions ?
tgt_text.10834: Not at all, while I am what I am.
tgt_text.10835: If however I were contentious, or if a person of that kind were now present, he would say that I must abstain from them, and . would strongly object to what I say.
tgt_text.10836: But as we are poor creatures, do you wish I should venture to say what it is to know ?
tgt_text.10837: For it appears to me that it would be worth while to do so.

tgt_text.10846: but at present I do not remember.
tgt_text.10848: They say, I believe, that it is to have science.
tgt_text.10852: Let us, then, change it a little, and say that it is to possess science.
tgt_text.10854: But in what will you say this differs from that ?
tgt_text.10856: but whether it seems to differ or not, listen and examine with me.
tgt_text.10858: I will, if I am able.
tgt_text.10860: To possess, therefore, does not appear to me to be the same as to have:
tgt_text.10861: for instance, if any one having bought a garment, and having it in his power, should not wear it, we should not say that he has it, but that he possesses it.
tgt_text.10865: See then whether it is possible thus to possess science without having it:
tgt_text.10866: just as if any one having caught some wild birds, as doves or any others, and having constructed a dove­ cote at home, should feed them ;
tgt_text.10867: we should probably say that in some respects he always has them, because he possesses them :
tgt_text.10872: But in another respect we should say that he has none of them, but that he has acquired a power over them, since he has brought them under his control, in an enclosure of his own, so as to take and have them when he pleases, by catching whichever he wishes, and again of letting them go:
tgt_text.10873: and this he is at liberty to do as often as he thinks fit.
tgt_text.10877: Socr. Again, therefore, as in a former part of our dis­ cussion we constructed I know not what kind of waxen fig­ ment in the soul, so now let us make in each soul a kind of aviary of all sorts of birds, some being in flocks, apart from others, and others few together, and others alone, flying amongst all the rest wherever it may chance.
tgt_text.10882: While we are children, we must say, that this recep­ tacle is empty, and instead of birds we must understand sciences;
tgt_text.10883: whatever science, then, one has become possessed of and shut up in this enclosure, one must say that he has learnt or discovered the thing of which this is the science, and that this is to know.
tgt_text.10886: iSocr. Again, therefore, when any one wishes to catch any one of these sciences, and, when he has taken it, to have it, and again to let it go, consider what words he requires, whether the same as before, when he possessed them, or different ones.

tgt_text.10934: Will you, then, that we say, that we care nothing at all about words, in what way any one chooses to employ the words knowing and learning, but, since we have settled that it is one thing to possess a science, and another to have it, we maintain that it is impossible for a person not to possess what he does possess, so that it never happens that any one does not know what he knows, though it is possible for him to form a false judgment respecting it?
tgt_text.10935: For it is possible for him not to have the science of this particular thing, but another instead of it, when hunting after some one of the sciences that he pos­ sesses as they are flying about, he may by mistake take one instead of another;
tgt_text.10936: accordingly when he thinks that eleven is twelve, he takes the science of eleven instead of that of twelve, as it were taking a pigeon that he possessed instead of a dove.
tgt_text.10938: It is reasonable to suppose so.
tgt_text.10940: But when he takes that which he endeavours to take, then he is not deceived, and judges truly:

tgt_text.10942: Perhaps you agree with me, or what will you do ?
tgt_text.10947: We are freed then, from the dilemma of a man's not knowing what he knows :

tgt_text.11587: 3. Socr. But, my dear Euthyphron, to be laughed at is per­ haps of no consequence.

tgt_text.11995: I asked you, then, about a thing of this kind above, whether where the just is, there also is the holy, or where the holy is, there also is the just, but wherever the just is, there is not always the holy:

tgt_text.12008: Do you, then, also endeavour in like manner to teach me what part of the just the holy is, that I may tell Melitus no longer to treat me unjustly nor indict me for impiety, since I have now sufficiently learnt from you what things are pious and holy, and what not.
tgt_text.12010: That part of justice then, Socrates, appears to me to be pious and holy, which is concerned about our care for the gods ;

tgt_text.12071: That, Socrates, which slaves take of their masters.

tgt_text.12099: They are many and beautiful, Socrates.

tgt_text.12117: but the contraries to things accept­ able to them are impious, which also subvert and ruin all things.

tgt_text.12123: But now (for it is necessary that he who asks questions should follow the person questioned wherever he may lead) what again do you say is the holy, and holiness?
tgt_text.12124: Do you not say it is a knowledge of sacrificing and praying ?

tgt_text.12137: so that what you say will not fall to the ground.

tgt_text.12198: For you know it, if any man does;
tgt_text.12199: and I cannot let you go like Proteus, until you have told me.
tgt_text.12200: For if you had not known clearly both what is holy and what is impious, it is not possible that you could ever have attempted, for the sake of a hireling, to prosecute your aged father for murder;
tgt_text.12201: but you would have feared both to incur the anger of the gods, in case you should not act rightly in this matter, and would have been ashamed in the sight of men.
tgt_text.12202: But now I am sure that you think you clearly know both what is holy and what is not.
tgt_text.12203: Tell me, therefore, most excellent Euthyphron, and do not conceal from me what you believe it to be ?
tgt_text.12205: At some other opportunity then, Socrates:
tgt_text.12206: for now I am in haste to go somewhere, and it is time for me to depart.
tgt_text.12208: What are you about, my friend ?
tgt_text.12209: By going away you deprive me of the great hope I entertained that by learning from you what things are holy and what not, I might get rid of Melitus's indictment, by shewing him that I had now become skilled in divine things by the aid of Euthyphron, and that I no longer through ignorance speak rashly, or introduce innova­ tions respecting them, and that therefore I should lead a better life for the future.
tgt_text.12210: As Socrates was one day going from the Academy to the Lyceum he met with Hippothales, Ctesippus, and other youths, who were on that day celebrating the Hermæan festival in a newly-erected palæstra hard by.
tgt_text.12211: They invite him to come in and join their conversation;
tgt_text.12212: he promises to do so on condition that they will first tell him who is the beauty among them.
tgt_text.12213: Hippothales, to whom he first puts the question, shews, by his embarrassment, that he is himself far gone in love;
tgt_text.12214: and on being taxed with it by Socrates blushes still more, whereupon Ctesippus says that he is constantly overwhelming them with his poems and speeches on his favourite Lysis.
tgt_text.12215: Socrates, on hearing this, begs Hippothales to inform him how a lover ought to speak of or address his favourite.
tgt_text.12216: Hippothales, though he does not deny his being in love, does deny that he makes verses or speeches;
tgt_text.12217: but Ctesippus shews that he is constantly giving utterance to the most extravagant praises of his fa­ vourite and his family;
tgt_text.12218: on which Socrates remarks that he should not celebrate his victory before it is won ;
tgt_text.12219: for that it is not wise to praise the object of one's affection before a return of affection on his part is secured, and moreover such as are beautiful when highly praised are apt to become arrogant, and so are more difficult to be won.
tgt_text.12220: Hippothales takes these sug­ gestions in good part, and begs Socrates to advise him how to address his favourite so as to win his affection, which Socrates readily promises to do if they will give him an opportunity of conversing with Lysis.
tgt_text.12221: To this end they all enter the palm­ stra, and almost as soon as Socrates, Ctesippus, Menexenus and others had seated themselves down in a quiet corner, Lysis, who is very fond of listening to conversations, comes and takes his seat next his friend Menexenus, while Hippo­ thales is concealed in the back-ground out of sight of his favourite a.
tgt_text.12222: Socrates begins by addressing a few words to the latter, but on Menexenus being called out by the master of the palæstra, he turns to Lysis, and asks him whether his parents do not love him very much.
tgt_text.12223: On Lysis replying that they certainly do, Socrates shews him that though, since they love him, they must needs wish to make him as happy as possible, yet they are so far from letting him do whatever he pleases, that they put him under the government of others, even of slaves, and this not on account of his youth, but because he has not yet ac­ quired sufficient experience and knowledge to be entrusted with the government of himself;
tgt_text.12224: but that whenever he is wise enough, not only his father, but all others, will entrust him with the management of themselves and their affairsb.
tgt_text.12225: At this point of the conversation Menexenus returned and resumed his seat near Lysis, who begs of Socrates to say over again to Menexenus what he had been saying to him;
tgt_text.12226: but Socrates desires him to tell it himself on some future occasion, and for the present engages to converse on some other subject with Menexenus.
tgt_text.12227: Having observed, therefore, the friendship that subsisted between Lysis and Menexenus, he asks the lat­ ter, when any one loves another, which of the two becomes a friend of the other, the lover or the beloved ?
tgt_text.12228: Menexenus re­ plies that there is no difference.
tgt_text.12229: But Socrates shews that it frequently happens that a lover is not only not loved in turn, but is even hated.
tgt_text.12230: In that case, then, which is the friend ?
tgt_text.12231: Menexenus is forced to admit that unless both love neither can be a friend to the other.
tgt_text.12232: But here Socrates interposes this difficulty;
tgt_text.12233: he remarks that men often love horses, dogs, and other things which cannot love in turn;
tgt_text.12234: and the poet, as Menexenus admits, speaks truly who says, " Happy the man who has boys for his friends and horses and dogs," so that the beloved now appears to be a friend of the lover, and not the lover of the beloved;
tgt_text.12235: and by the same reasoning he who is hated is an enemy, and not he who hates, whence the absurd conclusion follows that people are beloved by their enemies and hated by their friends.
tgt_text.12237: therefore the reverse must be the case, and the lover must be a friend of the beloved. "
tgt_text.12238: If, then, neither those who love are to be friends, nor those who are loved, nor yet those who both love and are loved," who are to be called friends ?
tgt_text.12239: Lysis in­ terposes with the remark that they do not appear to him to have conducted their enquiries aright;
tgt_text.12240: so Socrates avails him­ self of the opportunity thus offered him, and directs his dis­ course to Lysis c."

tgt_text.12242: God ever conducts like to like," and the wisest among men say the same, " that like must ever needs be friendly to like."
tgt_text.12244: But, objects Socrates, only half of this appears to be true, for the more wicked men are the more hostile are they to each other;
tgt_text.12245: so that it appears that the good man only is a friend to the good man only, but that the bad man never arrives at true friendship.
tgt_text.12246: But here again a new doubt is started.
tgt_text.12247: The like can derive no benefit from the like;
tgt_text.12248: how, there­ fore, can they be held in regard by each other ?
tgt_text.12249: and how can that which is not held in regard be a friend ?
tgt_text.12250: In like manner, the good man is sufficient for himself;
tgt_text.12251: but he who is sufficient needs nothing, and so will not regard any thing, and therefore not love.
tgt_text.12252: So that from this it appears, that not even the good will be friends to each otherd.
tgt_text.12253: Socrates then remarks, that he once heard some one say that like is most hostile to like, and the good to the good;
tgt_text.12254: and ge­ nerally that things most like each other are most full of envy, strife and hatred, but such as are most unlike are most dis­ posed to friendship, just as the dry desires the moist, the cold heat, and so on.
tgt_text.12255: Menexenus admits the truth of this, and of its consequence, that the contrary is most friendly to its con­ trary.
tgt_text.12256: But again Socrates drives him to this absurd conclu­ sion, that since enmity is most contrary to friendship, therefore an enemy must be a friend to a friend, or a friend a friend to an enemye.
tgt_text.12257: Since it appears, then, that neither is the like friendly to the like, nor the contrary to the contrary, Socrates next pro­ poses to enquire whether that .
tgt_text.12258: which is neither good nor evil can be the friend of the good.
tgt_text.12259: According to an ancient pro­ verb, the beautiful is friendly, and the good is beautiful, whence he would conclude that that which is neither good nor evil is friendly to the beautiful and the good.
tgt_text.12260: There are three several classes of things, he says, the good, the evil, and that which is neither good nor evil.
tgt_text.12261: It has already been proved that the good is not friendly to the good, nor the evil to the evil, nor yet the good to the evil, nor the evil to the good ;
tgt_text.12262: it remains, therefore, that that which is neither good nor evil must be friendly to the good.
tgt_text.12263: But a little further discussion leads to the more narrow conclusion, that that which is neither evil nor good is friendly to the good, on account of the presence of evil f.Both Lysis and Menexenus agree to this conclusion;
tgt_text.12264: but Socrates soon raises new difficulties, and shews the fallacious­ ness of their former reasoning.
tgt_text.12265: A friend, he says, is a friend to some one, and for the sake of something, and on account of something;
tgt_text.12266: for a rich man is a friend to a physician on ac­ count of disease, which is an evil, and for the sake of health, which is a good, so that that which is friendly is a friend for the sake of a friend, on account of an enemy.
tgt_text.12267: By proceeding in this way, he argues, we shall at length arrive at some prin­ ciple, which will not have to be referred to another friend, but will arrive at the first friend, for the sake of which all other things are friends, and which is friendly for its own sake.
tgt_text.12268: Now it has already appeared that we are friendly to that which is good, and that we love the good on account of evil;
tgt_text.12269: if, therefore, evil were to be done away with the good would be of no use to us, and we should not love it.
tgt_text.12270: In this, too, his young friends are willing to acquiesce, but Socrates dispels this delusion also, and shews that evil cannot be the cause of love, since if evil were done away with the desires would still remain, which in reality are the causes of friendship;
tgt_text.12271: for that which desires desires what it stands in need of, and that which stands in need is friendly to that of which it stands in need:
tgt_text.12272: and so love, desire, and friendship respect that which, in a manner, belongs to a man;
tgt_text.12273: but then evil belongs to evil and good to good, consequently they will each severally be friendly to their fellow, and the evil will be no less a friend to the evil than the good to the good;
tgt_text.12274: but both these positions have already been shewn to be erroneous, and so no positive solu­ tion of the question proposed is arrived ats.
tgt_text.12275: I WAS going from the Academy straight to the Lyceum on the road outside the wall close to the wall itself, but when I reached the little gate, where is the fountain of the Panops, I there met with Hippothales son of Hieronymus, Ctesippus the Pseanian, and other young men with them standing together in a group.
